Conures

Red-Masked Conure

Famous as the stars of the movie 'The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill,' this conure is bright green with a full head and face of brilliant red.

Origin
Central & South America
Size
13 inches (33 cm). Weight: 160-200g (5.6-7 oz)
Weight
180g avg.
Noise Level
Very Loud. They have a loud, sharp call and are known to be quite vocal, especially in groups.

Looking for a Red-Masked Conure?

See Available Red-Masked Conure Listings

Species Ratings

Talking Ability 7/10
Noise Level 9/10
Social Needs 7/10
Cuddliness 9/10

Temperament & Personality

Intelligent, bold, and energetic. They are very social and can be affectionate, but they require good socialization to curb a tendency to be nippy.

Vocalization & Talking Ability

Fair to good talkers. They can learn a number of words and phrases and are good at mimicking sounds.

Dietary Needs

A varied diet is important. A base of pellets, supplemented with a wide range of fresh vegetables and fruits.

Health & Lifespan

Hardy birds with a lifespan of 25-30 years. They are known to form feral flocks in several US cities. Can be prone to PBFD.

Housing Requirements

Not recommended for apartments due to their high noise level. They need a spacious cage, at least 24"W x 24"D x 36"H.

Common Questions About Red-Masked Conure

What is the lifespan of a Red-Masked Conure?

The Red-Masked Conure typically lives for 25-30 years. With proper care, diet, and regular vet check-ups, they can live a full and healthy life.

Is the Red-Masked Conure good for beginners?

This species is rated as 'advanced' care level. They require specific attention, socialization, or dietary needs that may challenge first-time owners.

Where does the Red-Masked Conure come from?

The Red-Masked Conure is native to Central & South America.

More Conures

Dusky Conure

Moderate. While capable of loud calls, they are generally considered to be one of the quieter Aratinga conures.

Gold-Capped Conure

Loud. They have a strong, piercing call and can be quite vocal, especially when they want attention.

Golden Conure

Very Loud. They have a loud, harsh call that they will use frequently, especially if they are not the center of attention.
